Posts.Title: ductal carcinoma micro invasion

Posts.Content: On 9/7/2007 Leemg wrote: Marilyn,  Your post was quite intriging.  As far as an estrogen blocker.  If you have ER positive tumor it is necessary to block all estrogen production in you system.  It is not about a balance anymore.  The estrogen will feed or fuel any remaining cells or recurrence so it is definitely to your advantage to take one of the anti-estrogen blockers.  I'm on Femara and have had no ill side effects although I understand there are some who do.  What is intriguing it that you also have been diagnosed with thryoid cancer.  How did they determine that?  I also developed thryoid cancer and they estimate the process started about the same time my BC was diagnosed.  Unfortunately, it wasn't discovered until just recently and I'm now classified as stage 3 for the thyroid cancer, stage l for the breast as that was caught early.  It would be interesting to know if you have a family history of either breast or thyroid cancer.  I do not.  I'm actually in the process of asking my insurance co. to cover a blood test that links breast and thryoid cancer to a particular syndrome so it is very interesting that this has also happened to you.  I'm in my 50's.  If I may ask how old are you?  Would love to hear back!  Also the Femara does not complicate your treatment for thryoid cancer.  I was on Cytomel and felt good, will be going through RAI next week and then will be given Levoxyl to replace my thyroid function.  Hopes this helps! Thank you Leemg,  I am 57 and my breast cancer is a stage 1.  I did refuse chemo and it took a bit for me to agree to radiation.  It was during radiation that my neck began to swell. My rad onc had to convince me to continue with the treatments as I was feeling that the radiation was causing the swelling.  So had a biopsy after ultrasound indicated a problem.  As you are aware thyroid cancer is slow growing and there are some studies that link it to  breast cancer.  The thinking being that the thyroid cancer is present first.  I personally feel that if the thyroid cancer was found earlier ( meaning 5 to 8 years ago) I may not have developed breast cancer.  I did have symptoms of thyroid problems but doctors did routine test that I now know  are open to many interpretations.  My intuitive sence really knew something was wrong but I did not act on it as I trusted the testing more than I trusted myself at the time  This whole experience has taught me to trust my instincts more and that is why I question the use of inhibitors for me.  I am interested in finding more inf about progesterone for that reason   There is no history of breast cancer or thyroid cancer that I know of in my family my family kept a lot of secrets so who knows)  Good luck with your RAI.  I am awaiting the pathology from  the thyroid surgery I had last week.I am Levoxyl now.  I am interested in the  syndrome test you spoke of .  I would like to know how you are doing....thank you ...Marilyn
Posts.Title: Progesterone treatment for ER positive Breast cancer

Posts.Content: After recent lumpectomy  (er positive with no node involvement)and radiation treatments I am reluctant to take any aromatase inhibitors to inhibit estrogen production.  I am reading about using progesterone as a way to balance any estrogen dominance.  Does anyone have any experience with this or any more information. Two days after completing radiation I was diagnosed with Thyroid cancer and am being treated for this also.  I am reluctant to add any more treatments with possible  side effects.  Thank you for any information you can share with me....Marilyn

He ordered an ultrasound but that is not scheduled for two weeks.  I am considering stopping treatment until I get more information.  Please help with information if you can.  I must make this decision ASAP.  thank you
Posts.Title: Throid problems with BC radiation ?

Posts.Content: On 5/28/2007 Witchdoctor wrote: I am a radiation oncologist and it is unlikely the radiation is causing enlargement of the Thyroid during treatment or even after.  Are they treating lymphnode or just breast?  Are you on any other treatment, had chemo, hormonal etc.  The only possible way this could be irradiation is if they were treating an extensive field ie  Breast , Axillary LN, SC LN , Low Neck/Internal mammary.  If this is the case then it could just be swelling. More concerning in my opinion is it a recurrence/met to low neck or Thyroid.  Lastly it could be a fast growing thyroid tumor and you don't want that for sure.  It needs w/u to find out what it is.  It could be an after effect of hormones or even chemo if applicable. Thank you for your reply.  No chemo or hormones are involved in my treatment ( my decision not to take hormones) and my rad onc assures me he is just treating the breast.  It is a stage one cancer with no node involvment.  I am trying to schedule an ultasound sooner than the two weeks that havs been scheduled.  I still have a fear that radiation is causing this but it was helpful to hear from you...many thanks ...Mimi
Posts.Title: Throid problems with BC radiation ?

Posts.Content: On Oct 24, 2009 3:05 PM LRuth wrote: Hi:  I'm wondering if anyone else is feeling like me.  It's been 4 years since I was treated for stage I ductal carcinoma with a biopsy followed by 6 wks. radiation.  I am tired.  A lot.  I still pain in the area of the surgeries and tightness  and soreness below the spot.  I just feel like I have never completely recovered, or at least gotten my strength back like before the surgeries. Anyone else?? Thanks, Ruth       Dear Ruth, After receiving treatment for breast cancer (Stage 1-2 invasive ductal) I was diagnosed with thyroid cancer.  It seems that I was hypothyroid (Hashimotto"s) and had pappillary thyroid cancer.    The only reason I am mentioning this is that you may want to get your thyroid checked ,  not that you have another cancer, but that there is a connection for some women with thyroid problems and breast cancer   Any thyroid issues can make you extremely tired and unable to completely heal.  If you have not done so already you may want to see an endocronologist as they are prepared to do better testing for thyroid levels ( simple blood test)  The right Dr. can make all the difference.  I wish you well and send you healing thoughts. It is three years later for me and I am finally feeling like myself again.  Let me know if you want more information..Mimi
